importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Date of the last Trump-Putin phone call, which led to initial speculation about a near-term summit in Hungary.
Date of the previous Trump-Putin summit in Alaska, where initial ceasefire agreements were discussed and key demands were outlined.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period immediately following the Alaska summit, during which expectations for a Trump-Putin summit were high but have been dismissed by both US and Russian officials.

keyTakeAways: There are no plans for a Trump-Putin summit in the immediate future, according to US and Russian officials.
Russia has not changed its position on ceasefire conditions since the Alaska summit, insisting on control of Ukraine’s Donbas region and dismantling of its military capabilities.
The US expresses concern that Moscow is adopting a 'maximalist stance' and refusing to accept a ceasefire with frozen battle lines.
Trump has advocated for freezing the current battle lines as a starting point for negotiations, a position supported by Ukraine and European leaders.
Russia insists that territorial concessions and removal of Ukrainian military capabilities are essential for a lasting ceasefire, which Kyiv and allies consider unacceptable.
The lack of progress in negotiations has led to criticism from Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and European leaders, who accuse Russia of stalling and continuing military actions.
A private Russian communique to the US demanding control of Donbas contradicts Trump’s call for a stable, frozen front.
A phone call between US Foreign Minister Marco Rubio and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov has been held, but no in-person meeting is now deemed necessary.
Both the White House and Kremlin emphasize that serious preparation is needed, and no precise timeframe has been set for a future summit.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former President of the United States
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump is central to the narrative as a key political figure advocating for a ceasefire with frozen battle lines, and whose proposed meeting with Putin created global expectations.

namedEntities.name: Vladimir Putin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Putin is the central figure in Russia’s peace demands, maintaining a hardline stance on territorial control and military dismantling, which contradicts US and Ukrainian positions.

namedEntities.name: Volodymyr Zelenskyy
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Zelenskyy represents Ukraine’s position in the conflict, advocating for peace while criticizing Russia’s stalling tactics and refusal to accept frozen battle lines.

namedEntities.name: Marco Rubio
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: US Senator and U.S. Secretary of State (in context of the article)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rubio is involved in diplomatic back-and-forth with Russia’s foreign minister, indicating active US engagement in peace negotiations.

namedEntities.name: Sergey Lavrov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Lavrov is Russia’s diplomatic representative in peace talks, reiterating Moscow’s unchanged demands and engaging in direct communication with US officials.

namedEntities.name: Hungary
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hungary was proposed as a location for a Trump-Putin summit, which has now been ruled out by both sides.

namedEntities.name: Alaska
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The 2025 Alaska summit set the foundation for current ceasefire discussions, with both leaders agreeing on certain principles but diverging on key conditions.

namedEntities.name: Donbas region
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A key point of contention, as Russia demands control of the Donbas region, which contradicts Trump’s call for a frozen front.

namedEntities.name: Ukraine
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ukraine is the primary nation affected by the war and central to the peace negotiation dynamics, especially in response to Russian demands.

namedEntities.name: European leaders
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: European leaders support Ukraine’s position and criticize Russia’s inaction, reinforcing international pressure on Moscow to compromise.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Officials from the United States and Russia have dismissed expectations of an imminent Trump-Putin summit, with both sides stating that no plans exist for such a meeting in the near future. The delay stems from a fundamental disagreement over ceasefire conditions: Russia demands control of Ukraine’s Donbas region and dismantling of its military, while Trump and Ukraine advocate for freezing the current battle lines. A private Russian communique and diplomatic calls between US and Russian foreign officials have failed to resolve the impasse, with Moscow insisting it has not changed its position since the August Alaska summit. The US and Ukrainian leaders criticize Russia’s maximalist stance and ongoing military actions, highlighting the growing international concern over stalled peace efforts.
title: 'No plans' for Trump-Putin summit in near future, officials say
